orientation.Incident Commander / Manager: Confirm you will own declaration timing, team communications, and DOE-417 sign-off gates.
orientation.Technical Responder: You will practice isolating systems, preserving evidence, and advising on recovery readiness.
orientation.Compliance / Evidence: Watch for evidence capture points, CIP-008 reporting clocks, and DOE-417 triggers.
orientation.General Staff / Reporter: Focus on spotting indicators, reporting quickly, and staying inside approved guidance.
orientation.Observer (read-only): Follow the gated flow to see how roles branch and how evidence is logged.

scope.Incident Commander / Manager: Track when a cyber event becomes reportable and when to notify the Incident Management Team.
scope.Technical Responder: Note containment levers you can use without jeopardizing forensics or BES reliability.
scope.Compliance / Evidence: Map each lifecycle phase to artifacts you will catalog for audits and CIP-008 R3 evidence.
scope.General Staff / Reporter: Remember the first call path: supervisor or SOC, then stay available for follow-up.
scope.Observer (read-only): Observe how the lifecycle and definitions are surfaced for each audience.

plan.Incident Commander / Manager: Decide when to transition from response to recovery and who authorizes return to service.
plan.Technical Responder: Align investigation steps to the plan: evidence first, containment second, recovery after validation.
plan.Compliance / Evidence: Identify which steps generate chain-of-custody entries and reporting deadlines.
plan.General Staff / Reporter: Capture the streamlined checklist—who to alert, what not to touch, and how to document.
plan.Observer (read-only): Follow how the plan references Appendix B workflow and Appendix C decision criteria.

execution.Incident Commander / Manager: Practice delegating tasks, approving communications, and recording decisions with timestamps.
execution.Technical Responder: Apply technical triage, isolation, and recovery validation without overwriting evidence.
execution.Compliance / Evidence: Coordinate DOE-417 reporting prep while tracking artifacts and chain-of-custody.
execution.General Staff / Reporter: Use the quick reference to report and then avoid speculative actions.
execution.Observer (read-only): Confirm each role follows the documented script and checklists.

etiquette.Incident Commander / Manager: Model concise answers and defer to SMEs for technical depth while keeping scope tight.
etiquette.Technical Responder: Reference tickets, hashes, and evidence IDs instead of theorizing root cause.
etiquette.Compliance / Evidence: Frame answers with retention rules, time sources, and reporting thresholds.
etiquette.General Staff / Reporter: Keep responses to observed facts and who you notified.
etiquette.Observer (read-only): Notice deferral language and how it protects scope.

mock.Incident Commander / Manager: Expect decision points about severity, team communication, and when to contact IMT/RC.
mock.Technical Responder: Expect choices about isolation methods, recovery validation, and evidence preservation.
mock.Compliance / Evidence: Expect CIP-008 R3 evidence prompts and DOE-417 timing questions.
mock.General Staff / Reporter: Expect prompts on reporting suspicious activity and avoiding system changes.
mock.Observer (read-only): Explore alternate roles to see how branching feedback changes.

quiz.Incident Commander / Manager: Anticipate communication, declaration, and recovery authorization questions.
quiz.Technical Responder: Anticipate analysis, containment, and eradication decision checks.
quiz.Compliance / Evidence: Anticipate reportability and evidence trail requirements.
quiz.General Staff / Reporter: Anticipate recognition and reporting cues with minimal jargon.
quiz.Observer (read-only): Awareness only; see how each role is graded.

shared: Timestamp all actions with the same authoritative clock and record who approved them.
Capture ticket, log, or evidence IDs for every action and communication.
Never speculate root cause during the event—stay on documented facts and thresholds.

responsibilities: Authorize declaration, external notifications, and containment moves.
Coordinate communications to SOC, IMT, RC/BA/TO, and leadership using the documented matrix.
Approve recovery plans and decide when to return systems to service after validation.
expectations: Show decision logs from detection through follow-up and who was notified when.
Clarify when the event met Appendix C reportability and who signed DOE-417.
Demonstrate how team members were assigned and briefed on roles.
never: Bypass evidence handling to accelerate recovery.
Skip notifying Compliance when reporting thresholds are met.
Declare all-clear without technical validation and checklist completion.
checklist: Confirm incident classification (Cyber Event vs. Incident vs. Attempt) using Appendix C.
Notify SOC/IMT/leadership and document timestamps for each audience.
Authorize containment, approve communications, and open DOE-417 draft if reportable.
Review recovery validation and declare return-to-service when clean.
Schedule lessons learned and assign follow-up owners.

responsibilities: Validate alerts, collect volatile evidence, and protect chain-of-custody.
Contain impact with approved isolation steps while keeping forensics intact.
Lead recovery validation, ensuring clean backups and hardened rebuild steps.
expectations: Document hashes, evidence storage, and who handled each artifact.
Explain containment choices and when systems were returned to service.
Provide remediation notes for lessons learned and hardening.
never: Patch or reimage before evidence is captured.
Disconnect critical assets without coordinating reliability impact.
Return systems to production without verification scans and approvals.
checklist: Validate indicator and capture logs/screenshots with timestamps.
Isolate affected hosts using approved playbook steps; record ticket numbers.
Change credentials or revoke access per containment guide.
Restore from trusted backups or rebuild; verify with scans and peer review.
Document technical lessons and monitoring adjustments.

responsibilities: Catalog evidence, owners, and retention timelines across all phases.
Track reportability, DOE-417 deadlines, and E-ISAC/CISA distribution lists.
Maintain the incident record, including CIP-008 R3 updates and follow-up actions.
expectations: Show synchronized timestamps and storage locations for each artifact.
Demonstrate the decision trail for reportable vs. attempt classifications.
Produce the completed DOE-417 draft and submission confirmation when required.
never: Edit technical evidence without SME confirmation.
Let reporting clocks lapse without escalation.
Share incident data outside approved distribution lists.
checklist: Update incident log with classification, owners, and time sources.
Capture hashes/locations for all evidence; maintain chain-of-custody entries.
Decide reportability with Incident Commander; prep DOE-417 and send to E-ISAC/CISA.
Record recovery approval, return-to-service time, and validation notes.
Publish lessons learned summary and file evidence for audit.

responsibilities: Recognize and report suspicious activity immediately to supervisor or SOC.
Preserve the scene: avoid unplugging devices or deleting evidence.
Follow communications guidance and stay reachable for updates.
expectations: Know the first-call list and what details to include (who, what, when, where).
Avoid speculative statements and defer to the response team for next steps.
Complete the simplified checklist before considering the task done.
never: Attempt to fix or reboot affected systems on your own.
Share incident details outside approved channels.
Ignore follow-up requests from the response team.
checklist: Report immediately to SOC or supervisor with observable facts.
Do not alter the system; capture the time and what you saw.
Follow instructions on isolation or power if told by the response team.
Log who you notified and when; keep contact information handy.
Review the quick-reference card before returning to normal duties.

responsibilities: Observe adherence to the script and log gaps for process improvement.
Note which artifacts prove each lifecycle phase.
Share feedback on clarity and usability after the exercise.
expectations: Identify where evidence is stored and how timing is verified.
Spot communication bottlenecks or scope creep risks.
See how reportability decisions are documented.
checklist: Review each module completion and confirm gating works as designed.
Capture observations on clarity, timing, and evidence traceability.
Provide improvement notes to the training owner.
